title.narrative: Women and Girls for Change South Sudan (2020)

description.narrative: The project aim is to create an empowering and inclusive environment, where women and girls feel safe and are enabled to realize their rights and opportunities, to play a significant role towards sustainable peace. We do this via a establishing a community based (psychosocial) support mechanism for women and girls.

recipient-country.narrative: Key features of South Sudan society are pervasive insecurity and deeply entrenched gender inequality, both of which are linked to various ongoing cycles of violence. Aside from the ongoing national political conflict, the country has for many years experienced concurrent inter- and intra-communal conflicts. In 2013, political tensions among the political leadership led to eruption of violence and civil war. Ethnically targeted killings started in the capital Juba spreading fast to the rest of the country, with devastating effects on the lives and livelihoods of thousands of civilians, exacerbating a food crisis in the country, and placing women and children, especially girls, at greater risk of severe forms of sexual and other forms of gender-based violence (SGBV). In August 2015, the South Sudanese Government and the opposition signed a peace agreement but in July 2016 fighting broke out again, causing new streams of refugees and internally displaced populations (IDPs). For the younger generation, avenues for political advancement are scant, and especially (young) women have limited options to engage in conflict resolution or peace building efforts, as this is a domain where usually male elders dominate.

title.narrative: 1.1.2 Follow-up, case management and referral by PFPs of W/G in need of focused psychosocial and/or mental health support
# of communities with a functional and effective community-based psychosocial support mechanism for women and girls

location.ref: Unity (Payinjar county) (Southern Unity) Lakes (Yirol West county) Eastern Equatoria (Nimule and Torit counties)

comment.narrative: 7 communities supported in Lakes, Unity and Eastern Equatoria

title.narrative: 1.1.1 Facilitate training and mentor community based Psychosocial Focal Points (PFPs) on mapping and detection, referral, follow-up, psychosocial care and case management

location.ref: Unity (Payinjar county) (Southern Unity) Lakes (Yirol West county) Eastern Equatoria (Nimule and Torit counties)

comment.narrative: Q1 4 PFPs mentored remotely Q2 8 PFPs mentored remotely; Q3 8 PFPs mentored remotely

title.narrative: # Psychosocial Focal Points (PFPs) trained and mentored as supervisors

location.ref: Unity (Payinjar county) (Southern Unity) Lakes (Yirol West county) Eastern Equatoria (Nimule and Torit counties)

comment.narrative: Q1: training with PFP supervisors canceled due to COVID-19 measures. Q2: 8 PFPs supervisors were trained/ mentored remotely. Q3: 7 PFPs (5F/2M) received 5-day training in Juba (1 was on bereavement leave)
